title: Essay on Shiny Apps
text:
1 ğŸš€ Introduction to Shiny
Shiny is an R package that allows you to turn your R scripts into interactive web applications without needing HTML, CSS, or JavaScript knowledge.



2 ğŸ§± Key Components of a Shiny App
A basic Shiny app has two key parts:



Component
Description




ui (User Interface)
Controls the layout and inputs/outputs


server
Contains the logic to handle input/output and computation




2.0.1 âœï¸ Basic Example

library(shiny)

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Lucky number"),
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      sliderInput("num", "Choose a number:", 1, 100, 25)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      textOutput("result")
    )
  )
)

server <- function(input, output) {
  output$result <- renderText({ paste("You selected:", input$num) })
}

shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)




â¸»


2.0.2 ğŸ’¡ Why Use Shiny?

Great for interactive dashboards
Powerful for data exploration and simulation
Enables non-programmers to interact with data

â¸»


2.0.3 ğŸ“¦ Deployment Options

Local: Run directly in RStudio
Shiny Server: Host internally
shinyapps.io: Cloud-hosted deployment

â¸»


2.0.4 ğŸ§  Summary
Shiny is an excellent tool for building reactive, user-friendly applications that make your R analysis come alive.

title: Essay on Shinylive
text: Shinylive allows you to run Shiny apps entirely in the browser, powered by WebAssembly. No R server or shinyapps.io is required.

title: Essay on Shinylive
text: Shinylive allows you to run Shiny apps entirely in the browser, powered by WebAssembly. No R server or shinyapps.io is required.

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
2 âš™ï¸ How Shinylive Works

Your R code is compiled to WebAssembly
The entire app runs client-side in the browser
Itâ€™s deployed as a static HTML file

title: Essay on Shinylive
section: 3 ğŸ” Shiny vs.Â Shinylive â€“ Whatâ€™s the Difference?
text:
3 ğŸ” Shiny vs.Â Shinylive â€“ Whatâ€™s the Difference?



Feature
Shiny
Shinylive




Server Required
âœ… Yes
âŒ No


Hosting
shinyapps.io, etc.
GitHub Pages, Quarto Pub


Reactivity
Server-side
Browser-side (client)


Setup
More complex
Easier / Static files


Performance
Scales well
Lightweight

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
4 âœ… Pros of Shinylive

Easy to share: just host static files
No server maintenance
Great for small tools, teaching, or personal demos

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
5 âš ï¸ Cons of Shinylive

Performance may lag for large apps
Limited support for some R packages (e.g., those that require C/C++ backend)
No persistent storage or backend features

title: Essay on Shinylive
text:
6 ğŸ§  Summary
Shinylive is a game-changer for small, serverless R apps â€” fast, simple, and ideal for educational content, prototypes, or personal portfolios.
Use Shiny for enterprise apps. Use Shinylive for quick sharing.

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
text:
# web scraping
url <- "https://www.imdb.com/chart/top/?ref_=nv_mv_250"

raw_script <- read_html(url) |>
  html_element("script#__NEXT_DATA__") |>  # Escape the id selector
  html_text()

top_movies <- str_match_all(raw_script, '"titleText":\\{"text":"(.*?)"')[[1]][,2]
year <- str_match_all(raw_script, '"releaseYear":\\{"year":(\\d{4})')[[1]][,2]
rating <- str_match_all(raw_script, '"aggregateRating":(\\d+(\\.\\d+)?)')[[1]][,2]

# Create as a dataframe
top250_movies <- tibble::tibble(
  title = top_movies,
  year = as.integer(year),
  rating = as.numeric(rating)
) |> 
  arrange(desc(rating))

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
text:
ğŸ¬ Overview
This dashboard visualizes the IMDb Top 250 movies, showing trends in ratings and allowing interactive exploration by year.

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
text:
ğŸ† Key Highlights






ğŸ¬ Highest Rated Movie



The Shawshank Redemption with a rating of 9.3








ğŸ•°ï¸ Oldest Movie



Released in 1921








ğŸ†• Newest Movie



Released in 2024

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
text:
ğŸ“ˆ Rating Distribution

ggplot(top250_movies, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of IMDb Ratings", x = "Rating", y = "Count")

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
section: ğŸ“Š Number of Top Movies by Year
text:
ğŸ“Š Number of Top Movies by Year

top250_movies |>
  count(year) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_col(fill = "coral") +
  labs(title = "Number of Top Movies by Release Year", x = "Year", y = "Number of Movies") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: IMDb Top 250 Movie Dashboard
text:
ğŸ” Movie Look Up

reactable(
  top250_movies,
  searchable = TRUE,
  filterable = TRUE,
  defaultPageSize = 10,
  columns = list(
    title = colDef(name = "Movie Title"),
    year = colDef(name = "Year"),
    rating = colDef(name = "Rating", format = colFormat(digits = 1))
  )
)

title: Welcome to Pin-Yi Chenâ€™s Portfolio
text:

Welcome to my personal Quarto website for Module 10. This site showcases interactive visualizations and educational resources that explore Shiny apps, Shinylive, and dashboard building in R.

ğŸš€ Step 2: Essay on Shiny Apps






Tip



In this section, I explain what Shiny is and how it can be used to build interactive web apps with R. Designed as a lecture note to guide coworkers new to Shiny, youâ€™ll learn about ui, server, and how to deploy a basic app.
ğŸ‘‰ Read the Essay on Shiny Apps




ğŸŒ Step 3: Essay on Shinylive






Tip



Shinylive allows Shiny apps to run entirely in the browser â€“ no R server needed! In this lecture, I explain the technology, pros and cons, and key differences from traditional Shiny apps.
ğŸ‘‰ Read the Essay on Shinylive




ğŸ“Š Step 4: Interactive Dashboard






Tip



An interactive dashboard built using Quarto and R! Explore IMDb Top 250 movies by rating, release year, and more â€“ with search filters and visual summaries.

ğŸŒ Publishing Info

âœ… This site is published to both Quarto Pub and GitHub Pages.
Built with â¤ï¸ using R, Quarto, Shiny, and Shinylive.
